title: Red-Eyed Tree Frog Temperature & Humidity Guide
description: Complete guide to maintaining proper temperature gradients and humidity levels for Red-Eyed Tree Frogs, including heating equipment, misting schedules, and seasonal adjustments.

content.heading: Why Temperature & Humidity Are Critical
content.text: Red-Eyed Tree Frogs (Agalychnis callidryas) come from tropical rainforests where temperature and humidity remain remarkably stable year-round. Their physiology is adapted to this narrow environmental range: daytime temps of 75-85°F (24-29°C), nighttime slight drop to 68-75°F (20-24°C), and average humidity of 70-75% with brief morning/evening peaks to 90% from rain/fog. Unlike some hardy species that tolerate wide fluctuations, Red-Eyed Tree Frogs are INTOLERANT of temperature extremes or prolonged low humidity. Overheating causes fatal metabolic stress within hours, while chronic low humidity leads to dehydration, failed sheds, and respiratory infections. Their highly permeable skin makes them especially vulnerable - they absorb moisture and regulate temperature through skin contact, not just respiration.

content.text: Temperature GRADIENT is more important than hitting exact numbers. Frogs need choices - warm basking area + cooler retreat zones.
NEVER exceed 85°F (29°C) anywhere in enclosure. Red-Eyed Tree Frogs overheat rapidly and can die within 2-4 hours of exposure to 90°F+.
Proper gradient requires strategic heat source placement combined with vertical enclosure design:

items: Heat Source Placement: Position basking light over one upper corner of enclosure (not center). Creates warm zone in upper canopy, cooler zone diagonally opposite.
Vertical Stratification: Hot air rises - upper third naturally warmest (basking zone), middle third ambient, lower third coolest (near water).
Water Section Cooling: The aquatic zone acts as heat sink, cooling the lower area. This is why paludariums maintain better gradients than dry terrariums.
No Floor Heating: Under-tank heaters not recommended for arboreal species - frogs don't bask on ground. Heat lamps + water heater only.
Multiple Thermometers: Place digital thermometers at three heights: top (basking), mid-level (ambient), and near water (cool zone). Monitor all three.

content.text: Primary Heating: Overhead Basking Lamps

items: 18°18°24? enclosure: Start with 25W, increase to 40W if needed
18°18°36? enclosure: Start with 40W, increase to 60W in cold rooms
24°18°36? enclosure: Start with 50W, increase to 75W in cold rooms

Room Temperature Adjustment: Add 15-25W if room temps consistently under 70°F

content.text: ALWAYS use a dimming thermostat or rheostat with heat lamps - prevents overheating if room temps rise unexpectedly. Never rely on bulb wattage alone.
Water Heating: Preset Aquarium Heaters

items: Recommended: Exo Terra Turtle Heaters - preset to 78-79°F (25-26°C), submersible, safe for frogs
Wattage: 25W for small paludariums (under 5 gallons water), 50W for medium (5-10 gallons), 75W for large (10+ gallons)
Placement: Fully submerge in water section, hide behind rocks/driftwood for aesthetics
Safety: Use heater guard or position where frogs can't directly contact heating element
Monitoring: Check water temp daily with separate thermometer - heater thermostat can fail

content.text: Stable water temperature is CRITICAL for breeding. Fluctuating water temps confuse frogs' seasonal cues and suppress breeding behavior.
Red-Eyed Tree Frogs require a nighttime temperature DROP to maintain natural circadian rhythms:

items: Target Drop: 5-10°F (3-6°C) cooler than daytime - ideal nighttime range 68-75°F (20-24°C)
How to Achieve: Turn OFF basking lamp at night (use light timer). Ambient room temperature provides nighttime cooling.
If Room Too Cold: Use Ceramic Heat Emitter (CHE) on thermostat set to 70°F minimum. CHE emits no light, won't disturb nocturnal activity.
If Room Too Warm: Increase nighttime ventilation (small fan near screen top), reduce insulation. May need air conditioning in hot climates.
Water Section: Keep water heater running 24/7 - maintains stable 78°F water temp regardless of air temp.

content.text: Never use colored night bulbs (red/blue) or 'moonlight' LEDs near sleeping frogs - disturbs circadian rhythm and increases stress. Total darkness preferred.

content.text: Key concept: Humidity should CYCLE between 70-90%, not remain constant. Frogs need fluctuations, not static high humidity.
Manual Misting (Budget Option)

items: Equipment: Pump-action spray bottle with fine mist nozzle
Schedule: Heavy misting 2x daily (morning + evening), light misting midday if needed
Technique: Spray enclosure walls, foliage, substrate until water droplets visible. Avoid directly spraying frogs.
Duration: 30-60 seconds per session, adjust based on hygrometer readings
Pros: Free (after bottle purchase), allows you to inspect frogs during misting
Cons: Requires discipline (must be home twice daily), inconsistent if you travel

content.text: Automated Misting (Recommended)

items: System: Exo Terra Monsoon - programmable misting system with timer
Schedule: Program for 30-60 seconds at 7am, 12pm, and 7pm daily
Installation: Mount nozzles in upper corners pointing down, connect to reservoir, set timer
Maintenance: Refill reservoir weekly, clean nozzles monthly (prevents clogs)
Pros: Consistent misting even when away, longer misting duration possible, hands-free
Cons: $80-120 investment, requires reservoir refills, nozzles can clog

content.text: Ultrasonic Humidifier (Supplemental)

items: Use Case: Boost baseline humidity in dry climates (under 40% ambient room humidity)
Placement: Direct fog tube into lower enclosure vent - fog rises naturally
Schedule: Run 1-2 hours in morning, 1-2 hours in evening (not 24/7)
Distilled Water Only: Prevents mineral buildup on glass and plants
Caution: Can over-humidify if not monitored - use with hygrostat for automatic control

content.text: Never use humidifiers 24/7 or keep humidity above 75% constantly - creates perpetually wet conditions that breed bacteria. You need DRY periods for air exchange.
Paludarium design inherently boosts humidity through natural evaporation:

items: Water Section: 25-30% water coverage provides constant evaporation, stabilizes humidity without equipment
Live Plants: Transpiration from Pothos, Philodendron, ferns releases moisture into air
Moist Substrate: Forest moss and leaf litter retain water and slowly release humidity
Waterfalls/Drippers: If installed, increase surface area for evaporation (but also require more maintenance)
Enclosed Design: Glass enclosure with screen top retains humidity better than open-air mesh cages

content.text: A well-designed paludarium with 30% water coverage may only need light misting 1-2x daily to maintain 70-75% humidity naturally.

content.text: Accurate monitoring prevents temperature/humidity disasters:
Analog dial thermometers/hygrometers are often inaccurate by 5-10°F or 10-20% humidity. Invest in digital equipment with remote probes.
Simulating seasonal changes triggers natural breeding behavior:
Dry Season Simulation (5-6 weeks):

items: Reduce photoperiod from 12 hours to 10 hours daily
Lower temperature to 72°F (22°C) daytime, 65-68°F nighttime
Reduce humidity to 60-65% by cutting misting to 2-3 times WEEKLY (not daily)
Lower water temperature to 70-72°F (21-22°C)
Feed sparingly - 2x weekly instead of every other day
Purpose: Simulates cooler, drier winter period frogs experience in wild

content.text: Rainy Season Transition (Breeding Trigger):

items: Increase photoperiod back to 12 hours daily
Restore temperatures to 75-85°F daytime, 70-75°F nighttime
Increase humidity to 80-85% sustained by misting 3-4x daily for 60-90 seconds
Restore water temperature to 78°F (25-26°C)
Resume normal feeding (every 2-3 days)
Simulate 'heavy summer rains' with 2-3 minute misting sessions for 1-2 weeks
Males will respond with mating calls and amplexus attempts

content.text: The dramatic shift from dry season to rainy season is the primary breeding trigger. Gradual transition doesn't work - frogs need abrupt environmental change.
High humidity + poor ventilation = bacterial infections. You MUST balance both:

items: Full Screen Top: Non-negotiable. Never cover screen with towels, plastic, or solid lids to boost humidity.
Cross-Ventilation: Ideal setups have both top screen AND lower back/side vents for air circulation.
Natural Airflow: Hot air rises through top screen, pulls fresh air in from bottom vents. This passive circulation prevents stagnant air.
Small Fan (Optional): Very low-speed fan directed across (not into) screen top during day improves air exchange without excessive drying.
Signs of Poor Ventilation: Condensation on walls lasting 4+ hours after misting, musty smell, excessive mold growth, frogs developing skin lesions.

content.text: If you cannot maintain 70%+ humidity WITH full screen ventilation, your misting is insufficient - do NOT reduce ventilation to compensate.

content.text: If Enclosure Overheats (over 88°F):

items: Immediately turn off all heat sources
Mist heavily with room-temperature (NOT cold) water
Place frozen water bottles wrapped in towels near (not touching) screen top
Move frogs to coolest room in house if possible
Monitor for signs of heat stress: gaping mouth, lethargy, dark coloration, twitching
If stress signs present, seek emergency vet care - overheating can be fatal

content.text: If Enclosure Too Cold (under 65°F):

items: Add CHE on thermostat immediately
Insulate sides (NOT top) with foam board or towels temporarily
Move enclosure away from drafty windows/doors
Check water heater is functioning - frogs may seek warm water if air too cold
Prolonged cold causes immune suppression and respiratory infections

content.text: Power outages in winter can be fatal. Have battery-powered backup thermometer and emergency heat source (hand warmers, insulated transport container) ready.

content.text: Your local climate determines which parameter (temp vs humidity) requires more attention. Identify your challenge and invest equipment accordingly.
